utterances: (Soundbite of music)
Did you have to wear spandex tights like Salt-N-Pepa?
Yeah.
But that's when spandex was in.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's when they're in.
Yeah.
We started a movement with that.
I'm sure, you know, you might remember.
Oh, I do.
You might have hair on yourself.
I did.
You know, we started a few of those trends, and let me apologize to all you ladies out there that lost your hair from the whole blonde thing, you know, the spandex thing, we did it all.
We did the polka dots.
We did the spandex.
You know, it was really fun.
What do you think was different from the moment in time when you guys were say doing, ""Push It"" or ""Let's Talk About Sex"" and today?
It seems in a way - we recently spoke with Monie Love and some other pioneering female artists.
And it seems like today, there's even less space for female rappers and DJs than there might have been in the past.
You know, I think there's a movement going on right now where I've been doing a lot of traveling, doing my DJ gigs.
And I meet a lot of artists - female - that don't care anymore.
They're just out there and they're doing it because they have passion.
And that's what it's really going to take again.
It's going just be like not trying to match a standard, but just doing what you love and doing it, and building your own audience.
Well, now you have a syndicated radio show.
It's called, ""The Backspin.
Mm-hmm.
What do you play?
We play the gamming.
We play a lot of old school hip-hop.
Anything from De La Soul, A Tribe Called Quest, KRS-One.
Come one, man.
Eric B and Rakim.
You Must Learn.
Yes.
Yes.
My philosophy - I mean D-Nice, we play, you knowâ€¦
You've taken me back.
Rage.
We played Monie Love.
We played Latifah.
You know, a lot of people today that listen to the show, they're a whole other generation and they might not remember or they might not have been there.
They may have been babies or perhaps wasn't even born, you know.
So you get a whole new audience that wants to know and they love it.
What would you like to do?
I mean, obviously, music is your life.
But if there's anything that you haven't done like business-wise or even adventure-wise, what would it be?
I'm really working on my Web site right now.
That's really it.
And, of course, there's some TV opportunities down the line.
You know, Salt-N-Pepa is doing their show, the VH1 show.
Yeah.
Well, yeah.
I didn't know that it was confirmed.
Tell me about that.
It's confirmed.
VH1 is doing the Salt-N-Pepa reality show.
I'm a guest on it.
I'm not going to be a regular on it.
And I'm going to be just as curious as you all out there about, you know, about the show.
But it's basically the two of them, just cameras following them trying to put this thing together again.
I'm like it's a no damn brainier.
You don't have to do 10 episodes to figure this out.
When you say put this thing together, rejoin.
Reunion.
Oh.
Would you tour with them if they did?
Can I say, hell yeah?
Yeah.
(Cheering).

But sometimes I feel like there's a lot of negativity, not just in what people talk about, you know, with the big issues, but just also a sort of fatalism that's come in to what people rhyme about like nothing will ever change.
And you guys, when you're like, ""Let's Talk About Sex,"" to me, it really was about change.
It was like we can make a difference.
Now, if you remember back then?
We were walking this line and I remember the feeling when we were putting out those songs, like they're going to think we're corny.
They're going to think we're bubble gum.
They're going to think we're this.
You know, I remember having a little bit of (unintelligible) of resistance.
When we would comment on things like ""Let's Talk About Sex,"" they were issues going on that it made sense to do.
You know, out of control teen pregnancies.
You know, the whole AIDS epidemic was rising at the time.
It was just off the chain.
And now, we're back to that again.
So it's kind of like forget all that.
Let's do this again.
We could not only do good music.
We are ready for it.
We are primed for it.
And we're still relevant.
You know what I'm saying?
It seems like it's a door that needs to, you know, we need to go through again.
And I think it would be even better than ever.
Spin, thank you so much.
Thank you.
Thank you.
DJ Spinderella of Salt-N-Pepa is now the host of the syndicated radio show ""The Backspin.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Coming up on the program, Senator Larry Craig makes a direct case to the people of Idaho why he should stay in office.
But first to Pakistan.
Today, Benazir Bhutto described what it was like to be the target of a deadly suicide attack.
It happened yesterday in Karachi just a few hours after the former prime minister had returned to Pakistan after nearly eight years of self-imposed exile.
Bhutto escaped unhurt, but more than 130 people were killed, many more wounded.
Among them, many party workers, security men, and policemen.
NPR's Philip Reeves is in Karachi, where Bhutto gave a news conference earlier today.
Bhutto says she knew her convoy was going to be attacked, as it drove slowly through the streets of Karachi, greeted by a crowd of hundreds of thousands of her supporters.
She said this was a risk she was prepared to take for her people and her land.
Speaking on a poor sound system, she described what happened to a crowded press conference in Karachi today.
She called for an investigation into one issue in particular.
The attack happened in the dark, after midnight, local time.
Why, she asked, had the street lights along the route been shut off?
I know that if the streetlights have been on, our guards would have spotted the suicide bombers, because they have been trained to look out for the suicide bombers.
Bhutto said her party officials were so worried by the missing streetlights that they tried to telephone Pakistan's national security adviser, but couldn't get through.
She said an hour before the attack, a man with a pistol had been arrested.
And before that, party workers reported finding someone with a suicide belt.
As she traveled along in her armor-plated truck, accompanied by the high command of her Pakistan People's Party, her security guards began taking measures of their own.
They began shining lights into the crowd.
We had floodlights and we were scanning the crowd with the floodlights.
But it was difficult for us to scan the crowd because there was so much darkness that (unintelligible) not see.
For much of that journey, Bhutto had ridden on the top of the truck waving at the crowds.
But when the attacks started, she was inside.
It began with the explosion of a grenade and then a much larger blast.
We saw the - first the sound and saw the huge orange light and bodies spilling all over.
Bhutto also said her convoy was shot at.
We know shots were fired, and they fired towards the trucks.
These were shots that were fire either immediately before the suicide bombing stopped the truck or immediately after the suicide bombing, to fire - kill the people who were there.
